No one is excluded from worship in the temple. There are certain requirements that must be met before one can attend.

As in the days of Christ’s mortal ministry, temple attendance requires spiritual preparation.

In today’s temples, you must be at least eighteen. Have a recommendation from your bishop and stake president, and prepared yourself to serve in the House of the Lord. Typically fasting and prayer are the preparation some undertake.

We are not “doing” anything to anyone.

If you read the Bible, you will see that access to the temple was always restricted, and that only those who have made the proper covenants and who have “clean hands and a pure heart” may enter. If you have not made and kept the proper covenants with God, there is no benefit in entering the temple.

You quote Jesus to argue that we should not restrict access to the temple, but Jesus literally beat people with a whip and physically threw them out of the temple because they were not supposed to be there. It is literally the only example of physical violence that we have on the part of Jesus - and He did it twice. So maybe restricting temple access to only the earnest faithful was important to Jesus…?

We do not keep anyone from going to the temple. We invite and encourage everyone to attend the temple. But one must take the proper steps to do it, or going to the temple is worse than pointless. It is childish and ignorant to demand access to the temple when you have not properly prepared.

Why does The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints not allow some of its congregation into its temples? Jesus said, "Whatsoever You Do to the Least of My Brothers You Do unto Me"; Matthew 25:40.

It is not the case that the Church does not allow some of its members to enter the Temple. Rather it is the case that everyone who enters the temple needs to be ready to do so.

The reasons why a person is not yet ready can vary. It may be because they are too young, or because they have not been a member of the Church long enough, or because they are not yet living in a way that is compatible with

Why does The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints not allow some of its congregation into its temples? Jesus said, "Whatsoever You Do to the Least of My Brothers You Do unto Me"; Matthew 25:40.

It is not the case that the Church does not allow some of its members to enter the Temple. Rather it is the case that everyone who enters the temple needs to be ready to do so.

The reasons why a person is not yet ready can vary. It may be because they are too young, or because they have not been a member of the Church long enough, or because they are not yet living in a way that is compatible with the covenants they will make in the Temple.

But whenever a member approaches their bishop for a Temple Recommend, the answer is never “no.” It will either be “yes” or “not yet.” Everyone is invited to prepare to enter the Temple.

How many times can you receive your endowment in the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (LDS Church) before you are considered worthy to enter a Mormon temple on your own without having a companion present with you?

You receive your endowment in a single session in the temple. When you go for endowment sessions in the future you will be doing the ordinance for someone who is dead. Worthiness to enter the temple has nothing to do with how many times you have been there. You never have to have someone with you, although it is recommended to have an escort for your first time to help make sure you are in the right places.

Alan Brown's answer to Why does the LDS Church not allow some of its congregation into its temples? Jesus said, "Whatsoever You Do to the Least of My Brothers You Do unto Me"; Matthew 25:40.

Of course, Brown notes so very often that he turned to Christianity, presumably LDS, 35 years ago. And it was 40-ish years ago that the LDs changed its rules on different races becoming clergy (my bolding):

Forty years on, most US Mormons still believe the racist priesthood/temple ban was God's will

Just to explain this policy, until 1978 any Mormon of African descent was prohibited entrance into the Church’s temples for ordinances such as sealings and endowments. This effectively barred them from entering the highest level of heaven after death (the Celestial Kingdom), which Mormons believe can only be obtained by people who have received those ordinances in the temple.

The ban also prohibited men of African descent from holding the LDS priesthood, despite historical evidence that several black men were ordained to the priesthood under Joseph Smith before Brigham Young forbade it in 1852.

The 2016 NMS asked whether respondents felt that the ban on members of African descent was “inspired of God and was God’s will for the Church until 1978.”

Alan says “ I am grateful that His Gospel is immutable!” but I guess it is only immutable after 1978! Or, LDS people don’t know the details of their own religion.

It does not appear that the Mormon practice of religion is very similar, at all, to such Christianity as was practiced among early Christians.

Among other things, early Christians had nothing like such temples as the Mormon church builds and maintains today. There is no evidence they participated in anything like the temple endowment ceremonies — which ceremonies are in many of their elements either identical to or near identical to Masonic rituals that Smith learned when he became a Mason. There is no evidence that early Christians had a centralized and highly-organized hierarchical leadership

It does not appear that the Mormon practice of religion is very similar, at all, to such Christianity as was practiced among early Christians.

Among other things, early Christians had nothing like such temples as the Mormon church builds and maintains today. There is no evidence they participated in anything like the temple endowment ceremonies — which ceremonies are in many of their elements either identical to or near identical to Masonic rituals that Smith learned when he became a Mason. There is no evidence that early Christians had a centralized and highly-organized hierarchical leadership structure, such as the Mormons. There is no evidence they had an organized and elaborate priesthood, such as today’s Mormons maintain. There is no evidence that any early Christian group had large and widespread property holdings, and/or any significant wealth, such as does the Mormon church.

There is no evidence early Christians had any concept regarding three degrees of heaven, or of the need for any ordinances beyond baptism. There is no evidence they endorsed the practice of men having multiple simultaneous wives. In fact, Paul recommended, generally, against being married at all. There is no evidence they subscribed to anything like the concept of eternal marriage, to be achieved only via special ordinances performed in special places.

As for the comparison that some other answerers on this question make the to the Jewish temple in Jerusalem, actually, that temple was generally open to all. It was only the inner sanctums where entry was restricted, and even that fails as a parallel to Mormon practice in regard to its temples. The restriction in regard to entry to the inner sanctums was based on genealogical lineage. In particular, one had to be a descendant of Aaron.

Certainly, it would seem on the face of it that the Mormon practice of excluding the less than perfect from their temples flies in the face of Jesus’ Matthew 25:40 admonition. It seems on the face of it to fly in the face of Jesus warming embrace of harlots, and other sinners that “good Jews” of the time treated as unworthy and despicable. It would seem indeed that Mormons have created an “elite righteous” on par with the devout Jews, whom Jesus himself seemed pretty much to despise.

So, why does the LDS church only allow some of its congregation into its temples? It appears it’s because (and very contrary what we see in the New Testament as the Jesus presented there), Mormonism has created an “elite righteous,” and temples are reserved for only this elite.

The excuse of their temples being a holy place that would be defiled if any but the righteous entered seemingly fails when it’s considered that: (a) Jesus himself never felt defiled when in the presence of the unrighteous; and (b) in the only historical example of special temple edifices, from Jerusalem, general admittance was open to all.

Mormons claim that their church and its practices are the result of a “restoration” from early Christianity. The evidence, quite frankly, does not even begin to line up.

Logan R. Kearsley

In the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (Mormons), "Temple ordinances are not needed or performed" for babies who are stillborn or miscarried. Why?

Babies who are not born live are necessarily in one of two possible states:

  1. Never “ensouled”, and so not people. There's nothing there to do ordinances for.
  2. Ensouled, but dead prior to the age of moral accountability, and thus saved by default.

One can quibble over when exactly an embryo or fetus becomes a person, and “miscarriage” is a broad enough term that it could plausibly fall on either side of that line wherever you choose to draw it—but either way, no mortal ordinances are needed.

Do you believe in astrology, and why or why not?

I never used to believe in Astrology and would hate it when my parents would follow it. But as life is unpredictable, I ended up believing in it and became one of those. Below is my story:

I often come across this question from my friends in a very astonishing way, “How come you into Astrology?,” as I had mocked everyone who ever talked about astrology. However, today I can share my journey with everyone.

Back in 2013, I quit my job with Nomura to pursue my dreams but things didn’t go as planned and I struggled for a year and exhausted my savings. To make ends meet, I went back to Mumbai and did some odd jobs as I was not getting shortlisted for any technology job interviews, citing a gap of one year. After some networking, an old colleague referred me to BNP Paribas and I got the job at a pay cut.

After working there for a year, I got in touch with one of my school friends, who later went to IIT Delhi, and we both planned to start an IT services company. It was time to put down the papers yet again, and I typed the resignation letter with full enthusiasm (that time I didn’t have to look for email templates on Google) but I got very anxious before sending it, as the old struggling days started haunting me.

As I was staring dead at the resignation email, one of my colleagues came over and inquired, “Is everything okay? You look lost.” I showed her my resignation letter and told her how my negative thoughts are not letting me do what I wanted to.

She looked at me with empathy and said, “I can see your birth chart and tell you what to do as per Astrology. What are your birth details?” and she opened one very badly designed app on her phone to input my details. I was shocked and amused at the same time. I promised myself to hire good UI/UX designers to develop better apps than that).

“Seriously? Do you think I believe in all this? Padhe likhe hoke aap andh vishwas faila rahe ho!” I scolded her but I wished I could get some help.

She waited for me to complete and demanded, “Are you done? Now tell me your birth details. I don’t care if you believe or not but let me try to help.” I shared the details as I would rather not mess with a senior. But knowing her coding skills, I could totally judge that she would screw up in Astrology as well.

As she was analysing my chart, I waited curiously to know the outcome, the way I had waited for my 10th standard board results. There is something about Astrology, it doesn’t matter whether you believe in it or not, but it fascinates you like nothing else. However, as I didn’t trust her and would never have liked to take a biased decision based on Astrology, so I quickly sent the resignation letter and locked my screen. Meanwhile, she was done with her calculations and it was time for the results.

“You are Leo Ascendant and your Sun is exalted…” I interrupted her in between and asked, “I don’t understand all this. Tell me something about the past to make me believe you,” I was such a spoiler.

“Beta, jitna tu bhaagta hai na isse, aage jake utna jaada believe karega (Dear, as much as you are mocking this today, you will believe in it much more, in future),” She mocked me this time but after hearing that I was convinced she knew Astrology as good as Database designing, as I would never do that.

“You don’t choose Astrology, Astrology chooses you”

Then she told me many things about my past to make her point including the date of my accident in school days, which was shocking. And once she observed the change in my body language, she stopped telling about the past and came to the main question. She not only predicted the past correctly but was also such a nice observer of behaviour. Oh God! Why the hell was she a MySQL developer?

“Yes, you can quit your job as the next two years are very promising for an IT business as per the placement of Saturn and Rahu,” she smiled as she made the prediction. I am still not sure if that smile was for a positive prediction or for the virtual win over me.

“Just two years?,” I exclaimed with a sheepish laugh as I had to pretend that I was not interested.

Like every other story, this story was also filled with some twist and turns. The twist was that my business partner might leave after two years from then and I would face some issues in resuming the business and it might take a year to pivot to a new venture, “But you will make it” she assured after observing my not-so-good body language.

“You can press the send button,” she finally said something with a real smile as she observed that I wasn’t mocking anymore and had surrendered myself, unlike a Leo.

After that, I served my notice period and came to Noida and started an IT services company named CodeYeti in April 2015. We managed to scale up very quickly to 45 employees, serving about 15-20 clients at a time and clocked a revenue of $0.5 million in the first year itself. We started working for big enterprises like Yamaha, GreenPly along with startups.

Everything was going well until my partner told me that he is not getting a kick from the services business and wanted to do a tech product. We spent the next six months on two products but ended up wasting capital as nothing seemed to work and he finally quit in March 2017 to do something else.

And that reminded me about the prediction, my ex-colleague had made about my partner’s exit. I called her after a gap of two years (Let’s just assume that I was busy and was not bad at keeping in touch) and told her about the prediction.

I could sense the happiness in her voice as her prediction came true but she showed concern as it was a loss for me. To my surprise, she knew everything about CodeYeti as she followed our social media channels and congratulated me for what we had achieved in such a short duration.

“Do you want me to check your chart again?” she inquired.

I paused for a moment and proposed an idea, “How about I start a product in the field of Astrology and I become your first customer?” She halted for a few seconds and said, “Hmmm…I had quit my job four months back for some personal reasons, and I can take out some time to work with you but I won’t be very active, so you will have to find more astrologers. I can connect you with a few in my network”

“Yes Yes! You can work whenever you have time and you can interview and train other astrologers and we will keep hiring. You can become their mentor and take care of the department of Astrologers”, I said in excitement.

“Hmm…So, when are we going live?” she straight away asked for a deadline, the way she did at BNP. Some people never change.

And then, there was the ultimate turn – I worked on developing the product and launched an MVP (minimum viable product) of AstroTalk within a month and assigned a dedicated technology & operations team to it. I called her as a customer and asked, “How would AstroTalk do?”

Why are The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints temples closed to the public?
Originally Answered: Why are Mormon (The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints) temples closed to the public?

The temples of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints are in and of themselves offerings to God. They represent the very best God’s people can afford to construct.

Accordingly, access is strictly controlled.

Doesn’t it make sense that a building should be limited to those who support and work towards the building’s intended purpose? My home is open to my children, their children and to a limited extent any friends of the family—but it is a home, it is a special place for my family.

Likewise, the temple is a special place for families who belong to the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day

The temples of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints are in and of themselves offerings to God. They represent the very best God’s people can afford to construct.

Accordingly, access is strictly controlled.

Doesn’t it make sense that a building should be limited to those who support and work towards the building’s intended purpose? My home is open to my children, their children and to a limited extent any friends of the family—but it is a home, it is a special place for my family.

Likewise, the temple is a special place for families who belong to the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. It is where members of the Church of Jesus Christ make the very covenants that will allow the family to be sealed together forever. We see no obligation to expose sacred things to those, who like some of the folks who have answered this question, can only mock and deride those things that they cannot or will not understand.

I can’t think of any building of comparable value to a temple of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints that would simply throw the doors open and let you nose around.

The public is invited to tour every temple before they are dedicated. Come and see. We make a huge effort to accommodate everyone who is interested. But once the building is offered to God, it becomes sacred.

Ask yourself what happens to buildings open to the public. Are you able to keep them as beautiful and peaceful as you would like?

Would you keep your own home open to the public?

I think there is are perfectly sound reasons for the controlled access to the temples of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints just as there are reasons for controlled access to just about every building you can think of.

What happens if a non-member of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints enters one of its temples?
Originally Answered: What happens if a non-Mormon enters a Mormon temple?

This is not a direct answer to the question but will illustrate that Mormons are definitely going to be prepared for any contingency:

I was once a tourist in downtown Salt Lake City with my wife and small child. We were crossing the street when my wife slipped on ice and went flying. She landed hard on her knees but didn’t appear to be badly hurt. She was carrying our baby in her arms, and miraculously she didn’t even wake up.

We got to safety on the sidewalk and determined that, even if she wasn’t badly hurt, she was still a mess. Her pants were torn and she was bleeding. We went to the nearest building, which happened to be one of the visitor’s centers on Temple Square, and I asked where the nearest rest room was. “My wife fell on ice and needs to get cleaned up.”

I don’t remember any passage of time at all until a well-dressed man appeared — I don’t recall him walking up, he was suddenly just THERE — and asked some quick questions about what happened. He asked where the accident had happened and I told him it was on the city street, not on Church property. I assumed that he was trying to establish liability issues for the Church and was a little resentful that this was the only thing they were interested in, until immediately they proved that they were not. He produced a walkie-talkie, again out of thin air, and INSTANTLY there was some kind of medical professional there, whether doctor or paramedic I can’t say, but my wife had her pants legs rolled up and he was evaluating the injuries. Then a woman appeared and led my wife into an area behind the desk where she got cleaned up, bandaged, and ready to resume our visit to Salt Lake City.

Here’s the point. Within SECONDS we were approached by security personell of both sexes, including medical service. If the Secret Service was there guarding the President of the United States they couldn’t have been more quick and efficient. They were unfailingly polite and courteous.

I have no doubt that if anyone wanted to get into the Temple, or anywhere else he or she was not supposed to be, that there would be trained security there instantly. Perhaps sooner.

Visitors are welcome in our regular meetinghouses. Services start at 9:00 am Sunday. Show up and we’ll happily guide you through our worship.

But our temples, like the temples of the Old and New Testament, are not open to the general public most times, because they are dedicated places of holiness.

Let's look at this logically:

The temple is the dedicated house of the Lord. Do you allow just anyone to go through your house? Don't we usually allow only those with the keys to unlock the door to enter? And we give keys to those we trust to protect and use the house according to our desires?

There is nothing that precludes anyone from doing what is required to gain that trust and earn the key, one requirement of which is joining the church. But those who have not are not welcome except at those times known as “Open houses,” which are relatively rare and occur before the dedication.

It is the same in our own homes as it is with God.

Can Latter-day Saints get tattoos while they are members?
Originally Answered: Can Latter-Day Saints get tattoos while they are members?

There is a federal law that prohibits Latter-day Saints from getting tattoos. Hence, they cannot get tattoos while they are members. If so, the prison term is severe.

OK, here’s the real answer… What prevents a member of The Church of Jesus Christ of latter-day Saints in getting tattoos? Nothing. Our leaders don’t do tattoo inspections. They don’t put us in chains if they find a tattoo someplace. In reality, we are free to do whatever we want. I have yet to have a bishop ever hold a gun to my head and tell me I can’t do something.

That said, the church teaches correct principles and we govern ourselves accordingly. The prophet has asked us not to get tattoos. The members, being aware of that, choose whether or not to be obedient to that counsel.

Original question: Has the LDS Church tried to buy the Kirtland Temple?

Neither The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints or the Community of Christ have made any such efforts public, but I’m sure it has been discussed. We have the resources to properly maintain the Temple. The Temple is less relevant to the Community of Christ than it was in decades past, and it is very possible that such talks will take place in the future. But we don’t know.

If such a purchase ever happens I would be great, but it is not essential to our doctrine. We make use of the Temple from time to time for meetings, youth conferences, and such. With the warm relations that now exist between the two churches, we would probably assist in the maintenance and upkeep of the Temple if we were asked (and it is possible that we do that now, but if we do, it is not something we draw attention to).

I’m just grateful that the former RLDS church has kept that building safe and intact over the years. To former RLDS and the current leadership of the Community of Christ, we owe a debt of gratitude. And not only for the Kirkland Temple, but other sacred historical sites as well.

What is the process for sealing a non-member of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (LDS) in the temple?

In order to be sealed in the temple, you must be a member of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints. Also, you must be a current valid temple recommend holder. In order for anyone who is a non-member to be sealed in the temple, we do sealings for those who have passed away. Nobody who is alive and a non-member can participate in temple ordinances.

Why is the LDS church building so many temples?

Original question: Why is the LDS church building so many temples?

Original question: Why is the LDS church building so many temples?

That is a good question. I can remember when there were 12 temples. Most of them were in Utah.

Our missionaries have been preaching in every corner of the world since the 1840s. Now the membership in far-flung regions is catching up. It’s been over 100 years since Church leaders stopped encouraging converts to come to Zion in the Rocky Mountains, and start building Zion wherever they live. I met a family in the Philippines, who in the 1960s had sold their house in order to afford to visit the temple.

Such sacrifices are becoming decreasingly necessary as temples are being constructed closer to the people. Now there are temples on every inhabited continent and many islands. Some of these are in places you might not expect, like Cabo Verde, Cambodia, Dubai, Hong Kong, and Zimbabwe. Today the dozen I knew as a child has multiplied by 15. There are 173 operating temples, 51 under construction or renovation, and 58 more announced.

In his closing remarks at the April 2021 General Conference, President Russell M. Nelson stated, “We want to bring the house of the Lord even closer to our members, that they may have the sacred privilege of attending the temple as often as their circumstances allow.”

The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints has been building temples since 1833. Of the 282 existing and future temples, President Nelson has announced 100 of them in the four years of his administration. So something is going on. He frequently mentions hastening the work in view of the Second Coming. Brigham Young (1803–1877) prophesied that there will be thousands, so we are still just getting started.

I hope this is helpful.

Who are allowed into the temples of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints?

When my brothers and I were young we did an annual 3-day hike, almost a pilgrimage, to High Creek Lake, in the mountains above Cache Valley, Utah.

(Image from The Trek planner)

We would plan for a month. We used the money we earned working on the farm to buy good backpacking equipment. We chose the perfect date, after the snow melt but before the spring dried up. We planned which trail we would use and whether we would stop at Naomi peak on the way. We would spend at least a couple of days packing our gear, including (and especially) our Count Chocula and freeze dried marshmallows. In the morning of the first day our mom would drive us up the dirt road as far as the truck would go, then we would unload and start the hike. We would then spend three glorious days; one day hiking up, another day playing at the lake, then hike down the other side to Tony Grove Lake on the last day.

So who is allowed to go to High Creek Lake? Of course everyone is allowed to go. It is a wonderful experience, and I’m not sure why everyone doesn’t do it. But not everyone does. First, you have to want it. You have to decide it is worth the effort, and you have to decide whether that’s where you really want to end up. Then you have to plan, prepare, and make the climb.

Before a temple is dedicated it is open to the public for an open house.

After the temple is dedicated everyone is still allowed inside, but with prerequisites. You have to learn the gospel, be baptized by those having authority, and demonstrate that you have repented and continue to live by some basic principles, generally for about a year.

And physically, at least, it is much easier than the hike to High Creek Lake.

Why is the LDS Temple so confusing?

First of all, I think you should understand that your reaction is not uncommon. I remember feeling confused and overwhelmed the first time I went through the temple as well. But that doesn't mean that attending the temple doesn't have great value, it just means that some additional work is required to appreciate some aspects of the experience. It is probably the case, for example, that many other doctrines of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints that seem relatively straightforward to you now, such as the Book of Mormon or the three degrees of glory, would be quite confusing to those who are not familiar with the LDS Church. But now you appreciate them and so you can see their merit. Similarly, the temple is a matter of familiarity, preparation and study.

Here are a few things I would suggest when considering your experience. One, when you say the temple is "confusing," I assume what you mean is that you did not understand the Endowment or the steps leading up to it. But remember that the Endowment is not the only, or even the most important, ceremony in the temple. You have presumably done baptisms for the dead? If so, consider your experiences there. What value did you gain from them? And if you have not participated in a sealing (which is the most important ceremony, in my opinion), then I would recommend that you do so. I have never participated in a sealing without being struck by the simplicity and beauty of the experience. Doing so may help you appreciate some of the other aspects of the temple.

Two, remember that the Endowment is meant to teach people in literally all walks of life--educated and uneducated; visual, auditory and tactile learners; relatively new converts and seasoned saints; people from all different countries and cultures. You can't create something like that and not end up with portions that are less appealing to some people at some times. If there are aspects of the ceremony that you don't understand, it may be that it's meant to appeal more to someone else. Focus on what works for you at the moment. There is plenty there for everyone, so you don't have to feel like it all makes sense at once. I personally think that the parts of the Endowment that don't speak as much to your typical North American saints, who are essentially raised in lecture-style classrooms, are precisely the ones that may be the most appealing to cultures that aren't used to learning in that way.

Three, allow yourself the opportunity to understand what you experienced better. Pray. Study the scriptures. (Note, for example, the complex temple rites of ancient Israel, which have a number of interesting parallels to what you experienced.) Go back to the temple, especially with those that you know well. Talk to people in the Celestial room, where you can be explicit about your questions. I have been really enlightened by things people pointed out to me in the Celestial room that I never would have thought of on my own. Exercise faith and give it time. The temple is a lot like the writings of Isaiah--potentially confusing and even off-putting at first, but deeply insightful, uplifting, and even gorgeous once you understand them. But you would never expect to appreciate Isaiah without working at it, would you?

As I said, the first time I went through the temple, I was also confused and overwhelmed. But now I find my attendance an absolute blessing and a deeply joyous thing. This is not to say that I understand all aspects of every ceremony, but that their meanings have become clearer to me. There is an awful lot going on there, and an awful lot that becomes clearer on repetition. To the extent you are looking for deeper things to chew on about life and LDS doctrine, the temple is chock full of them. There are parts of the temple that probably impact nearly every aspect of my thinking and outlook, and which I am always interested to consider again in more depth. As you continue to exercise faith, you will find the same.
Best of luck!

Why are The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints temples so huge?
Originally Answered: Why are The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (Mormon Church) temples so huge?

They’re not all huge. Some, like the Salt Lake City temple, are large.

Salt Lake City temple (Image source)

But others, especially ones built in the last 20 years or so, are much smaller. The Raleigh, North Carolina temple in Apex, for example, is fairly compact.

Raleigh Temple in Apex, North Carolina (Image source)

You’ll notice that it looks large, but that’s due mainly to its construction and central spire. In reality, it’s not much bigger that a normal chapel, in terms of pure square footage.

But they’re large due to the number of rooms they house. Each temple contain a few ordinance rooms, whi

They’re not all huge. Some, like the Salt Lake City temple, are large.

Salt Lake City temple (Image source)

But others, especially ones built in the last 20 years or so, are much smaller. The Raleigh, North Carolina temple in Apex, for example, is fairly compact.

Raleigh Temple in Apex, North Carolina (Image source)

You’ll notice that it looks large, but that’s due mainly to its construction and central spire. In reality, it’s not much bigger that a normal chapel, in terms of pure square footage.

But they’re large due to the number of rooms they house. Each temple contain a few ordinance rooms, which are used for sacred temple ceremonies. They also contain at least two changing rooms, where patrons can change into temple clothing. And, of course, they each have at least two restrooms. They also have offices for officials who work at the temple and a receiving area, like a lobby, where patrons can greet and wait for acquaintances.

Some have on-site cleaning facilities (for washing clothing) and some even have full cafeterias.

The ordinance rooms can vary in size, from the size of a large conference room to the size of a small movie theater. The ordinance rooms include:

  • Endowment room
  • Sealing room
  • Baptismal font
  • Celestial room

Of these, the baptismal font is probably the largest, as it contains a font, similar to this:

The oxen supporting the font represent the Twelve Tribes of Israel (Image source)

The Celestial Room can also occupy a good deal of space:

The Celestial Room is meant to suggest the Celestial Kingdom, or the highest degree of glory we all aspire to (Image source)

All these rooms together take up a lot of space. Larger temples often have multiples of these rooms, so they can accommodate more patrons.

Here is the official church site that goes into more details: Temples of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints - The House of the Lord

Do LDS Church members believe that their faithful Elders are all a “Priest forever after The Order of Melchizedek? Can not only Jesus Christ have this title? I asked once and requested, people have neglected to answer the question then…

Why are LDS temples being built in countries with tiny LDS congregations?

Latter-day Saint temples are being built all over the world. Our temples are places where sacred ordinances are performed and covenants are made for us individually and for our ancestors. It is also the only place where eternal marriages and sealings can be performed by those having the authority to do so.

Papeete Tahiti Temple

San Juan Puerto Rico Temple

Aba Nigeria Temple

Quito Ecuador Temple

Temples are being built in poorer countries to make it easier for those who do not have the ability to travel long distances to be able to attend the temple and perform saving ordinances and eternal marriages and sealings. All temples require a minimal number of worthy and active members to help run the temple. Temples are not built in countries where there are tiny congregations because they would be unable to fill all the temple worker positions required to perform ordinances. A minimal number of Melchizedek priesthood holders are required within an area for a temple to be approved for construction.

Do LDS temples have Windows?

Original question: Do LDS temples have windows?

Temple architects have adopted many styles, from Gothic Revival to Modernist. Most have some kind of windows, but many have very few. Some windows are merely decorative. A temple is a functional building with ornamentation, rather than an ornamental building with a function. All of these temples have more windows than Solomon’s temple.

Is a Temple of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints considered a Church?
Originally Answered: Is a Mormon Temple considered a Church?

No and yes. Mostly No.

We don't call it a church and we don't do things in there that we do in church (we don't meet as a group with whoever shows up from the community to sing or have gospel centered lessons or play basketball or attend a Boy Scout meeting.) But the things we do in the temple are things that others do in their churches (weddings, reflection/prayer/meditation.)

So no we don't consider it a church technically. But yes it is a religious building used for religious purposes, so we wouldn't be offended if, when playing SimCity, "temple" was just a leveled-up "church."

Does the LDS Church allow members to marry non-members in the temple?

Temple marriage is eternal marriage. It is only eternal marriage if you accept and living according to the covenants that make eternal marriage possible. And the God-given authority to perform an eternal marriage is only binding if the parties involved truly believe that said authority exists. So it doesn’t make sense for someone who is not a member of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints to even want to get married in the temple.

Members of the Church can absolutely get married to non-members outside of the temple. If said non-members would like to turn that into an eternal marriage

Temple marriage is eternal marriage. It is only eternal marriage if you accept and living according to the covenants that make eternal marriage possible. And the God-given authority to perform an eternal marriage is only binding if the parties involved truly believe that said authority exists. So it doesn’t make sense for someone who is not a member of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints to even want to get married in the temple.

Members of the Church can absolutely get married to non-members outside of the temple. If said non-members would like to turn that into an eternal marriage, they will need to commit to the covenants that lead to that.
